comments:
I have a project checked out from CVS in eclipse and when I try to remove the 
directories I very often have problems: everything gets removed except 
the "package.html" files. For those, I get a message that 
says "Resource '..../package.html' is out of sync with file system.'. I then 
refresh the project and try to delete again, but this doesn't help.

My workaround has been to delete the files on the actual filesystem and then 
do a refresh from within eclipse.

I am an eclipse user, not a developer so I don't know the eclise code-base, 
but I'm happy to try out any diagnostics on my end to figure this one out.

Also, I don't know if it helps, but here is an extract from the .log file that 
may or may not be relevant:

Failure to delete is usually caused by some other process having the file open.
Check for external editors that might have the file open, or command prompts
open inside the directories being deleted.

No, I don't have anything else accessing the file. But I just had the problem 
again (this time with some java files) and I did a refresh from within 
eclipse, at which point I could delete the files again. (The reason I was 
deleting the files was because "replace from HEAD" complains that it cannot 
delete certain files so I needed to manually delete them and then update the 
project".

I200411111200 runtime

I repeatedly saw this ResourceException in an automated test, but it's no longer
reproducible since I set up a new workspace to run the test with.

The test did:
- make 10 copies of a Java file
- open all copies in the text editor (not the Java editor)
- 4 times:
    - change all copies
    - save all copies
- delete all copies
-> the same exception starting with:
org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.ResourceException: Problems encountered
while deleting resources.
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.delete
(Resource.java:683)
[...]

Found while importing linked binary plugins over copied binary plugins. Is there
a way to find out which thread (if any) was holding a lock on the corresponding
workspace/system resource?

To answer the question in comment #5, there is no eclipse mechanism for finding
out what process or thread is reading a file.  Since reading a file requires no
locks, it is very difficult to find out (or control) who might be reading it. 
The latest stack trace shows failure to delete a JAR file, which I would suspect
is currently being read by the Java indexer at the time of failure.

Closing.  I have not been able to reproduce this failure.  Please reopen if you
have a test case that consistently reproduce the problem.  Any process or thread
on your machine could be reading these files, preventing the deletion.  Without
a reproducibe test there is no way to narrow this problem down any further.
